introduction.p: You may save your work at any time by clicking on Save. When you are finished working, click on Submit and Finish, a pop up window will ask "This will submit your answers and finish this assignment. Are you sure?", click "OK" if you are ready to submit your answers for final grading.
If you close this window without having saved or submitted, your changes will be lost. After pressing Submit and Finish, please wait for your answers to be scored. Do NOT click on it more than once.

body.p: The mortality rate from melanoma (skin cancer) during the 1950s was recorded for each of the 48 contiguous United States, plus Washington, D.C. (as reported by Fisher and Van Belle (1993) and found on http://www.stat.psu.edu/~lsimon/stat501wc/sp05/data/).
The following is the scatterplot of the data: The plot shows a negative linear relationship between the latitude of the state and melanoma mortality rate.
Which of the following is an appropriate interpretation of the negative relationship shown in the scatterplot above?

input.choice: The more southern the state, the higher the melanoma death rate.
The more northern the state, the higher the melanoma death rate.
The more southern the state, the more people that died of melanoma.

response.feedback: Correct. From the scatterplot we see that the lower the latitude the higher the mortality per 10 million. In other words, the more southern the state, the higher the death rate. Note that since the response variable is the mortality per 10 million, it measures the death rate rather than the number of deaths.
Incorrect. Notice that there is a negative linear relationship between latitude and mortality per 10 million. In other words, as latitude increases, mortality per 10 million decreases.
Incorrect. Notice that the variable mortality per 10 million is a rate, not an absolute count, of deaths from melanoma.

body.p: The mortality rate from melanoma (skin cancer) during the 1950s was recorded for each of the 48 contiguous United States, plus Washington, D.C. (as reported by Fisher and Van Belle (1993) and found on http://www.stat.psu.edu/~lsimon/stat501wc/sp05/data/).
The following is the scatterplot of the data: The plot shows a negative linear relationship between the latitude of the state and melanoma mortality rate.
Based on the scatterplot and the value of the correlation coefficient, it would make sense to test the significance of this observed linear relationship between latitude and melanoma mortality rate.
Which of the following are the appropriate null and alternative hypotheses?

ul.li: H0: Melanoma mortality rate is related to latitude
Ha: Melanoma mortality rate is not related to latitude
H0: Melanoma mortality rate is not related to latitude
Ha: Melanoma mortality rate is related to latitude
H0: Melanoma mortality rate is linearly related to latitude
Ha: Melanoma mortality rate is not linearly related to latitude
H0: Melanoma mortality rate is not linearly related to latitude
Ha: Melanoma mortality rate is linearly related to latitude

response.feedback: Incorrect. The null hypothesis should assume no relationship. Additionally, you are not testing just for any type of relationship but if there is a linear relationship between the variables.
Incorrect. You are not testing for just any kind of relationship between the variables. Specifically, you are testing if there is a linear relationship between the variables.
Incorrect.The null hypothesis should assume no relationship.

Correct. The hypotheses for testing the linear relationship between two quantitative variables is always: H0: the explanatory and response variables are not linearly related. Ha: the explanatory and response variables are linearly related.

body.p: The mortality rate from melanoma (skin cancer) during the 1950s was recorded for each of the 48 contiguous United States, plus Washington, D.C. (as reported by Fisher and Van Belle (1993) and found on http://www.stat.psu.edu/~lsimon/stat501wc/sp05/data/).
The following is the scatterplot of the data: The plot shows a negative linear relationship between the latitude of the state and melanoma mortality rate.
The following output is available:
Which of the following is an appropriate conclusion based on the output?

input.choice: The data do not provide sufficient evidence to conclude that melanoma mortality rate is linearly related to latitude.
The data provide extremely strong evidence that melanoma mortality rate is linearly related to latitude.
The data provide moderately strong evidence that melanoma mortality rate is linearly related to latitude.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Notice that the p-value in the Lat row is extremely small (approximately 0). This indicates that there is evidence of a relationship that melanoma mortality rate is linearly related to latitude.

Correct. The p-value is so small that the statistical software program reports that it is 0. This means that it would be essentially impossible to get data like those observed if melanoma mortality rate and latitude were not linearly related. This is extremely strong evidence that the two variables are linearly related.
Incorrect. Notice that the p-value in the Lat row is extremely small (approximately 0).

body.p: To determine if there is a relationship between grade performance and extracurricular participation, North Carolina State conducted a study of 112 students, recording the number of students in each of three extracurricular categories, and each of two grade categories. Here are the results: (Source: Felder, et. al., “A Study of Student Performance in an Introductory Chemical Engineering Course,” 1992 ASEE Annual Conference Proceedings, pp. 1516–1519.)
What is the expected count of students with high extracurricular participation and good grades?

response.feedback: Incorrect. This is the observed number of students with high extracurricular participation and good grades. We find the expected number of students with high extracurricular participation and good grades by assuming independence between extracurricular activity and grades. Then multiply the probability of having high extracurricular participation and good grades with the total number of people in the table.
Correct. The expected count is (row total * column total) / table total = 8 * 82 / 112 = 5.86.

Incorrect. This is the total number of observed students who had high extracurricular participation across both grade categories. We find the expected number of students with high extracurricular participation and good grades by assuming independence between extracurricular activity and grades. Then multiply the probability of having high extracurricular participation and good grades with the total number of people in the table.

Incorrect. This is the total number of students included in the study. We find the expected number of students with high extracurricular participation and good grades by assuming independence between extracurricular activity and grades. Then multiply the probability of having high extracurricular participation and good grades with the total number of people in the table.

body.p: To determine if there is a relationship between grade performance and extracurricular participation, North Carolina State conducted a study of 112 students, recording the number of students in each of three extracurricular categories, and each of two grade categories. Here are the results: (Source: Felder, et. al., “A Study of Student Performance in an Introductory Chemical Engineering Course,” 1992 ASEE Annual Conference Proceedings, pp. 1516–1519.)

The expected count of students with high extracurricular participation and good grades is the number of students that you would expect to see assuming that which of the following is correct? Check all that apply.

input.choice: The conditions that allow us to safely use the chi-squared procedure are met.
Extra-curricular participation and grade performance are related.
Extra-curricular participation and grade performance are independent.
The null hypothesis of the chi-squared test for independence in this case is true.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Calculating the expected count is not dependent on meeting the conditions of the chi-square procedure. Also, there is at least one correct assumption.
Incorrect. The expected count does not rely on the assumption that the categories related, but rather the opposite. Also, there is at least one correct assumption.

Incorrect. You are correct that, in general, the expected counts are the counts that we would expect to see if the two categorical variables are independent. However, there is at least one other correct assumption.

Incorrect. You are correct that, in general, the expected counts are the counts that we would expect to see if the null hypothesis of the chi-square test were true. Also, there is at least one other correct assumption.

Incorrect. Calculating the expected count is not dependent on meeting the conditions of the chi-square procedure. Also, the expected count does not rely on the assumption that the categories related, but rather the opposite. Lastly, there is at least one correct assumption.

Incorrect. You are correct that, in general, the expected counts are the counts that we would expect to see if the two categorical variables are independent. However, there is at least one other correct assumption. However, calculating the expected count is not dependent on meeting the conditions of the chi-square procedure. Also, there is at least one correct assumption.

Incorrect. You are correct that, in general, the expected counts are the counts that we would expect to see if the null hypothesis of the chi-square test were true. However, calculating the expected count is not dependent on meeting the conditions of the chi-square procedure. Also, there is at least one correct assumption.

Incorrect. You are correct that, in general, the expected counts are the counts that we would expect to see if the two categorical variables are independent. However, the expected count does not rely on the assumption that the categories related, but rather the opposite. Also, there is at least one correct assumption.

Incorrect. You are correct that, in general, the expected counts are the counts that we would expect to see if the null hypothesis of the chi-square test were true. However, the expected count does not rely on the assumption that the categories related, but rather the opposite. Also, there is at least one correct assumption.

Correct. In general, the expected counts are the counts that we would expect to see if the null hypothesis of the chi-square test (which claims that the two categorical variables are not related, or independent) were true. In this case, then, the expected counts are calculated assuming that extracurricular activity and grade performance are not related.

Incorrect. You are correct that, in general, the expected counts are the counts that we would expect to see if the two categorical variables are independent. However, there is at least one other correct assumption. However, calculating the expected count is not dependent on meeting the conditions of the chi-square procedure. Also, the expected count does not rely on the assumption that the categories related, but rather the opposite.

Incorrect. You are correct that, in general, the expected counts are the counts that we would expect to see if the null hypothesis of the chi-square test were true. However, calculating the expected count is not dependent on meeting the conditions of the chi-square procedure. Also, the expected count does not rely on the assumption that the categories related, but rather the opposite.

You are correct that, in general, the expected counts are the counts that we would expect to see if the null hypothesis of the chi-square test (which claims that the two categorical variables are not related, or independent) were true. In this case, then, the expected counts are calculated assuming that extracurricular activity and grade performance are not related. However, calculating the expected count is not dependent on meeting the conditions of the chi-square procedure.

Incorrect. You are correct that, in general, the expected counts are the counts that we would expect to see if the null hypothesis of the chi-square test (which claims that the two categorical variables are not related, or independent) were true. In this case, then, the expected counts are calculated assuming that extracurricular activity and grade performance are not related. However, the expected count does not rely on the assumption that the categories related, but rather the opposite.

Incorrect. You are correct that, in general, the expected counts are the counts that we would expect to see if the null hypothesis of the chi-square test (which claims that the two categorical variables are not related, or independent) were true. In this case, then, the expected counts are calculated assuming that extracurricular activity and grade performance are not related. However, calculating the expected count is not dependent on meeting the conditions of the chi-square procedure. Also, the expected count does not rely on the assumption that the categories related, but rather the opposite.
Incorrect. There is at least one correct assumption.

body.p: To determine if there is a relationship between grade performance and extracurricular participation, North Carolina State conducted a study of 112 students, recording the number of students in each of three extracurricular categories, and each of two grade categories. Here are the results: (Source: Felder, et. al., “A Study of Student Performance in an Introductory Chemical Engineering Course,” 1992 ASEE Annual Conference Proceedings, pp. 1516–1519.)
The following is the (edited) output of the chi-squared test in this case:
Using a significance level of 5%, based on the output which of the following is an appropriate conclusion?

input.choice: The data provide sufficient evidence to conclude that extracurricular participation and grade performance are independent.
The data do not provide sufficient evidence to conclude that extracurricular participation and grade performance are independent.
The data provide sufficient evidence to conclude that extracurricular participation and grade performance are related.
The data do not provide sufficient evidence to conclude that extracurricular participation and grade performance are related.

response.feedback: Incorrect. You are correct that the p-value below 0.05 provides sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis. However, the null hypothesis is that the extracurricular participation and grade performance are independent, so by rejecting the null you conclude the opposite (i.e. they are not independent).

Incorrect. Notice that the p-value is below 0.05. This implies that the data do provide sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis. Also, the null hypothesis is that the extracurricular participation and grade performance are independent, so by rejecting the null you conclude the opposite (i.e. they are not independent).
Correct. The p-value (0.046) is sufficiently small (less than 0.05) to reject H0 in favor of the alternative hypothesis and conclude that extracurricular activity and grade performance are related.

Incorrect. Notice that the p-value is below 0.05. This implies that the data do provide sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis that there is no relationship between extracurricular participation and grade performance and conclude that there is a relationship.

body.p: To determine if there is a relationship between grade performance and extracurricular participation, North Carolina State conducted a study of 112 students, recording the number of students in each of three extracurricular categories, and each of two grade categories. Here are the results: (Source: Felder, et. al., “A Study of Student Performance in an Introductory Chemical Engineering Course,” 1992 ASEE Annual Conference Proceedings, pp. 1516–1519.)
Which one of the following facts should make you the most worried about the reliability of the results of the test in this case?

input.choice: The 112 students were all students in a chemical engineering course and not a random sample from the entire student body.
Two of the observed counts are less than 5.
Not all of the cells' contributions to the chi-squared statistic are greater than 1.
Two of the six expected counts are less than 5.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Although these students are all from the same course, they are still randomly chosen.
Incorrect. The observed counts being less than 5 is not the most worrisome issue.
Incorrect. This just implies that some cells have expected counts and observed counts that are very close in value.

Correct. Since two of the six (or 33% of the) expected counts are less than 5. we should be concerned about the reliability of the results of the test. The fact that the random sample was not taken from among the entire university’s students but from a smaller sampling frame of students in a chemical engineering course should not harm the reliability of the test results (since the sample is still random) but should just affect how general our conclusions can be.

body.p: In a 2012 report from the US Department of Education breaking down the race and gender of every US college graduate receiving a bachelor’s degree in 2009-10, we see the following data for white, black and Hispanic graduates. (Numbers are in 1000’s.)
Source: “Degrees conferred by sex and race” National Center for Education Statistics, U.S. Department of Education https://nces.ed.gov/fastfacts/display.asp?id=72
What is the contribution of Hispanic females to the chi-square test-statistic?

response.feedback: Correct. You have calculated the chi-square contribution of Hispanic females to the test statistics as the square of the difference between the observed and expected counts of Hispanic females divided by the expected count of Hispanic females.

Incorrect. You have calculated the expected count of Hispanic females. We are looking for the contribution to the chi-squared statistic which is the square of the difference between the observed and expected counts of Hispanic females divided by the expected count of Hispanic females.

Incorrect. You have calculated the percentage of Hispanic graduates that are women. We are looking for the contribution to the chi-squared statistic which is the square of the difference between the observed and expected counts of Hispanic females divided by the expected count of Hispanic females.

Incorrect. You have calculated the difference between the observed and expected count of Hispanic female graduates. We are looking for the contribution to the chi-squared statistic which is the square of the difference between the observed and expected counts of Hispanic females divided by the expected count of Hispanic females.

body.p: In a 2012 report from the US Department of Education breaking down the race and gender of every US college graduate receiving a bachelor’s degree in 2009-10, we see the following data for white, black and Hispanic graduates. (Numbers are in 1000’s.)
Source: “Degrees conferred by sex and race” National Center for Education Statistics, U.S. Department of Education https://nces.ed.gov/fastfacts/display.asp?id=72
What is the chi-squared statistic for this data?

response.feedback: Incorrect. You may have calculated the contribution of black males which is only part of the chi-squared statistic. You need to add all 6 contributions to get the chi-squared statistic which is calculated by summing across all 6 cells the square of the difference between the observed and expected counts and dividing by the expected count for a given cell.
Correct. You have successfully calculated the 6 contributions to the chi-squared statistic and added them together following this formula:

Incorrect. You may have calculated the contribution of black females which is only part of the chi-squared statistic. You need to add all 6 contributions to get the chi-squared statistic which is calculated by summing across all 6 cells the square of the difference between the observed and expected counts and dividing by the expected count for a given cell.

Incorrect. You may have calculated the contribution of males which is only part of the chi-squared statistic. You need to add all 6 contributions to get the chi-squared statistic, not just the 3 for the males. This is calculated by which is calculated by summing across all 6 cells the square of the difference between the observed and expected counts and dividing by the expected count for a given cell.

body.p: Rainfall and corn crop yield reported for the 38 years from 1890 through 1927 give us the scatterplot shown below with an r = 0.0426. Yield is the number of ears of corn measured in metric tons per hectare, rainfall is in inches.
Based on corn crop yield from Ezekiel, M. and K. A. Fox. (1959). Methods of Correlation and Regression Analysis. Wiley: New York.
The plot shows a positive linear relationship between the inches of rainfall and the size of the corn yield.
Which of the following are is an appropriate interpretations of the relationship shown in the data shown above?

input.choice: The growth rate of corn is positively affected by more rainfall.
The more rain, the lower the yield of corn.
Rainfall seems to have a positive effect on the yield of corn.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Crop yield is the quantity (number of ears of corn) per area of land and does not tell us about how rainfall affects the growth rate of the crop.
Incorrect. More rain is correlated with a higher yield.
Correct. An appropriate interpretation is that rainfall seems to have a positive effect on the yield of corn.

body.p: Rainfall and corn crop yield reported for the 38 years from 1890 through 1927 give us the scatterplot shown below with an r = 0.0426. Yield is the number of ears of corn measured in metric tons per hectare, rainfall is in inches.
Based on corn crop yield from Ezekiel, M. and K. A. Fox. (1959). Methods of Correlation and Regression Analysis. Wiley: New York.
The plot shows a positive linear relationship between the inches of rainfall and the size of the corn yield.
Based on the scatterplot and the value of the correlation coefficient, it would make sense to test the significance of this observed linear relationship between latitude and melanoma mortality rate.
Which of the following are the appropriate null and alternative hypotheses?

choice.p: H0: Crop Yield is related to rainfall
Ha: Crop Yield is not related to rainfall
H0: Crop Yield is not related to rainfall
Ha: Crop Yield is related to rainfall
H0: Crop Yield is not linearly related to rainfall
Ha: Crop Yield is linearly related to rainfall
H0: Crop Yield is linearly related to rainfall
Ha: Crop Yield is not linearly related to rainfall

response.feedback: Incorrect. The null hypothesis should assume no relationship. Additionally, you are not testing just for any type of relationship but if there is a linear relationship between the variables.
Incorrect. You are not testing for just any kind of relationship between the variables. Specifically, you are testing if there is a linear relationship between the variables.

Correct. The hypotheses for testing the linear relationship between two quantitative variables is always: H0: the explanatory and response variables are not linearly related. Ha: the explanatory and response variables are linearly related.
Incorrect. The null hypothesis should assume no relationship.

body.p: Rainfall and corn crop yield reported for the 38 years from 1890 through 1927 give us the scatterplot shown below with an r = 0.0426. Yield is the number of ears of corn measured in metric tons per hectare, rainfall is in inches.
The following edited output is available:
The regression equation is Yield = 23.55 + 0.78 Rain
Which of the following is an appropriate conclusion based on the output?

input.choice: The data do not provide sufficient evidence to conclude that crop yield is linearly related to rainfall.
The data provide extremely strong evidence that crop yield is linearly related to rainfall.
The data provide moderately strong evidence that crop yield is linearly related to rainfall.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Notice that the p-value in the ‘Rain’ row is extremely small (0.0122). This indicates that there is evidence of a relationship that crop yield is linearly related to rainfall.
Correct. The p-value is 0.012 which means that samples like this would only happen by chance 12 times out of 1000. This is strong evidence that crop yield is linearly related to rainfall.
Incorrect. Notice that the p-value in the ‘Rain’ row is extremely small (0.0122). This is very strong evidence that crop yield is linearly related to rainfall.

body.p: In a 2012 report from the US Department of Education breaking down the race and gender of every US College Graduate receiving a bachelor’s degree in 2009-10 we see the following data for white, black and Hispanic graduates. (Numbers are in 1000’s.)
Source: “Degrees conferred by sex and race” National Center for Education Statistics, U.S. Department of Education https://nces.ed.gov/fastfacts/display.asp?id=72
Rounding to the nearest thousand, what is the expected count of white males?

response.feedback: Incorrect. This is the observed count of all reported males, not just whites. To calculate the expected count of white males multiply the total number of males by the total number of whites and divide by the total number of graduates.

Incorrect. This is the difference between the observed and expected counts of white males. To calculate the expected count of white males multiply the total number of males by the total number of whites and divide by the total number of graduates.

Incorrect. This is the observed count of white males. To calculate the expected count of white males multiply the total number of males by the total number of whites and divide by the total number of graduates.
Correct. To calculate the expected count of white males multiply the total number of males by the total number of whites and divide by the total number of graduates.

input.choice: The conditions that allow us to safely use the chi-squared procedure are met.
Race and gender are related.
The sample is large enough.
The null hypothesis of the chi-squared test for independence in this case is true.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Calculating the expected count is not dependent on meeting the conditions of the chi-square procedure. Additionally, there is at least one correct statement.
Incorrect. The expected count does not rely on the assumption that the categories related, but rather the opposite. Additionally, there is at least one correct statement.
Incorrect. You are correct that the sample is large enough (the expected counts for Hispanic males is larger than 5). However, there is at least one other correct statement.

Incorrect. You are correct that the sample is large enough (the expected counts for Hispanic males is larger than 5). body.p: In a 2012 report from the US Department of Education breaking down the race and gender of every US College Graduate receiving a bachelor’s degree in 2009-10 we see the following data for white, black and Hispanic graduates. (Numbers are in 1000’s.)
Source: “Degrees conferred by sex and race” National Center for Education Statistics, U.S. Department of Education https://nces.ed.gov/fastfacts/display.asp?id=72
The following is the (edited) output of the chi-squared test in this case:
Expected Values:
X-squared = 6.6251, df = 2, p-value = 0.03642
Using a significance level of 5%, based on the output which of the following is an appropriate conclusion?

input.choice: The data provide sufficient evidence to conclude that race and gender in the awarding of bachelor’s degrees are independent.
The data do not provide sufficient evidence to conclude that race and gender in the awarding of bachelor’s degrees are independent.
The data provide sufficient evidence to conclude that race and gender in the awarding of bachelor’s degrees are related.
The data do not provide sufficient evidence to conclude that race and gender in the awarding of bachelor’s degrees are related.

response.feedback: Incorrect. You are correct that the p-value below 0.05 provides sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis. However, the null hypothesis is that the gender and race are independent, so by rejecting the null you conclude the opposite (i.e. they are not independent).

Incorrect. Notice that the p-value is below 0.05. This implies that the data do provide sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis. Also, the null hypothesis is that the extracurricular participation and grade performance are independent, so by rejecting the null you conclude the opposite (i.e. they are not independent).

Correct. The p-value (0.036) is sufficiently small (less than 0.05) to reject H0 in favor of the alternative hypothesis and conclude that race and gender in the awarding of bachelor’s degrees are related.

Incorrect. Notice that the p-value is below 0.05. This implies that the data do provide sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis that there is no relationship between extracurricular participation and and conclude that race and gender in the awarding of bachelor’s degrees are related.
